description: From Middle English referren, from Old French referer, from Latin referre.

verbs.description: refer (third-person singular simple present refers, present participle referring, simple past and past participle referred)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To direct the attention of (someone toward something)
examples: The shop assistant referred me to the help desk on ground floor.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To submit to (another person or group) for consideration; to send or direct elsewhere.
examples: He referred the matter to the principal.
to refer a patient to a psychiatrist

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place in or under by a mental or rational process; to assign to, as a class, a cause, source, a motive, reason, or ground of explanation.
examples: He referred the phenomena to electrical disturbances.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To mention (something); to direct attention (to something)
examples: To explain the problem, the teacher referred to an example in another textbook.

definitionGroups.group: (intransitive, stative) To make reference to; to be about; to relate to; to regard; to allude to.

entries.meaning: (grammar) To be referential to another element in a sentence.
(intransitive, programming) To point to either a specific location in computer memory or to a specific object. [+ to (object)]
examples: In C, the pointer obtained by &a refers to the variable a.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, education) Required to resit an examination.
examples: Smith's marks in the finals were unsatisfactory and he was referred.

entries.meaning: (journalism) A blurb on the front page of a newspaper issue or section that refers the reader to the full story inside the issue or section by listing its slug or headline and its page number.
